articles.headline: New Ways to Treat Pain Meet Resistance
articles.snippet: For a number of reasons, alternatives to often-addictive painkillers are slow to be accepted, by insurers, doctors and patients.
articles.abstract: For a number of reasons, alternatives to often-addictive painkillers are slow to be accepted, by insurers, doctors and patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few months ago, Douglas Scott, a property manager in Jacksonville, Fla., was taking large doses of narcotic drugs, or opioids, to deal with the pain of back and spine injuries from two recent car accidents.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: House Democrats’ Gun-Control Sit-In Turns Into Chaotic Showdown With Republicans
articles.snippet: The standoff continued until early Thursday as the House speaker took the remarkable step of calling a vote on a major appropriations bill in the wee hours and without any debate.
articles.abstract: The standoff continued until early Thursday as the House speaker took the remarkable step of calling a vote on a major appropriations bill in the wee hours and without any debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Democratic protest demanding votes on gun-control legislation led to pandemonium in the House chamber that did not end until early Thursday, when Speaker Paul D. Ryan and his fellow Republicans reclaimed control long enough to force through a major spending bill. They then abruptly adjourned and left the Capitol.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Emmarie Huetteman

articles.headline: On Capitol Hill, Yellen Finds Partisan Heat, Not Economic Light
articles.snippet: Janet Yellen’s testimony before a House committee highlighted how real debate about the economy has been overshadowed by partisan politics.
articles.abstract: Janet Yellen’s testimony before a House committee highlighted how real debate about the economy has been overshadowed by partisan politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Year after year of disappointing growth in the United States. Disappearing middle-class jobs. Turmoil overseas, including the looming possibility that British voters will decide on Thursday to part ways with Europe. Urgent economic issues all.

articles.headline: ‘Brexit’ Vote Already Has a Winner: The Gambling Industry
articles.snippet: As Britain goes to the polls to determine whether to leave the European Union, bookmakers are anticipating record-setting gambling on the outcome.
articles.abstract: As Britain goes to the polls to determine whether to leave the European Union, bookmakers are anticipating record-setting gambling on the outcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ask for his opinion, and David Howe eagerly tells you how he hopes Britain will leave the European Union.

articles.headline: A Tour of Falluja Reveals Grim Remnants of Life Under ISIS
articles.snippet: Iraqi forces liberating the city are finding beheaded bodies, apocalyptic streetscapes and clumps of hair from fighters who shaved to blend in with fleeing civilians. Our reporter describes what he saw.
articles.abstract: Iraqi forces liberating the city are finding beheaded bodies, apocalyptic streetscapes and clumps of hair from fighters who shaved to blend in with fleeing civilians. Our reporter describes what he saw.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALLUJA, Iraq — As Iraqi forces move through Falluja, the city is yielding the grim remnants of more than two years of Islamic State rule. Beheaded and decaying bodies. Clumps of facial hair from fighters who shaved their beards to blend in with fleeing civilians. A prison where detainees were held in cages suitable for a medium-sized dog.

articles.headline: Fiat Chrysler Moves Up Gearshift Repairs After Death of Anton Yelchin
articles.snippet: The death of Anton Yelchin, which might be linked to a faulty gearshift in the Jeep Grand Cherokee, might have accelerated the repair schedule.
articles.abstract: The death of Anton Yelchin, which might be linked to a faulty gearshift in the Jeep Grand Cherokee, might have accelerated the repair schedule.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In an era of unprecedented scrutiny of automotive safety, Fiat Chrysler is learning that one celebrity’s death can turn a seemingly routine recall into a corporate crisis.

articles.headline: Acquittal in Freddie Gray Case Casts Doubts About Future Trials
articles.snippet: Officer Caesar R. Goodson Jr., who drove the van used to transport Mr. Gray, had faced seven charges, including second-degree murder.
articles.abstract: Officer Caesar R. Goodson Jr., who drove the van used to transport Mr. Gray, had faced seven charges, including second-degree murder.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The acquittal on Thursday of a Baltimore police officer charged with murder and six other crimes in the death of Freddie Gray has dealt a devastating blow to the prosecution, legal experts say, and raises questions about whether the state should press ahead with the trials of four other officers.
articles.byline: By Jess Bidgood and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Supreme Court Upholds Affirmative Action Program at University of Texas
articles.snippet: The case challenged a part of the admission program at the University of Texas at Austin that takes race and ethnicity into account.
articles.abstract: The case challenged a part of the admission program at the University of Texas at Austin that takes race and ethnicity into account.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday rejected a challenge to a race-conscious admissions program at the University of Texas at Austin, handing supporters of affirmative action a major victory.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Tie Blocks Obama Immigration Plan
articles.snippet: The 4-4 tie dealt a sharp blow to an ambitious program that the president had hoped would become one of his central legacies.
articles.abstract: The 4-4 tie dealt a sharp blow to an ambitious program that the president had hoped would become one of his central legacies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Thursday that it had deadlocked in a case challenging President Obama’s immigration plan, effectively ending what Mr. Obama had hoped would become one of his central legacies. The program would have shielded as many as five million undocumented immigrants from deportation and allowed them to legally work in the United States.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Britain’s Dreams of a ‘Swiss Miracle’ Look More Like Fantasy
articles.snippet: Supporters of a British exit from the European Union look to Switzerland, which rejected membership in 1992. But sovereignty from the bloc may be an illusion.
articles.abstract: Supporters of a British exit from the European Union look to Switzerland, which rejected membership in 1992. But sovereignty from the bloc may be an illusion.
articles.lead_paragraph: To help explain why the British voted to leave the European Union, look to Switzerland.
